content.description: This gear route follows the z-shaped crack to a pair of quicklink + Mussy anchors at the top. The route is a good choice for practicing trad gear placement with lots of options for cams and nuts almost the entire route. The crack zig-zag also emphasizes the importance of extended draws without being so long as to make it critical. You get good hand holds and nice foot holds on solid rock with a 5.7 crux in the middle, but it is 5.easier everywhere else.
content.protection: There are plenty of easy options for various pro from roughly 15mm to 80mm with a few spots for smaller and larger (but not necessary) gear. It has quicklinks and Mussy hooks anchor at the top. Traversing from either of the neighboring routes is simple if a toprope is desired.
content.location:
It is between

Smiley

and

Happy

on the eponymous crack.

content.description:
This route is described in the Jim Shaw "

Fraser Valley Climbs

" guidebook as ending on the overhanging opposite wall. If it is climbed in this above fashion, the route is 3 bolts tall ending on the overhanging opposite wall on 2 Mussy hooks. Rope drag appears to be high using these anchors.

We climbed the first 3 bolts as described above then moved slightly left connecting the the last bolt on

Scary

and using the 2 Mussy hooks on

Scary

as anchors for

Stone

making this option 4 bolts tall.

Details: this route is short and hard, and sharp holds protect the crux. Assume the stem is not part of the route and would downgrade it accordingly.
content.location: It is the furthest uphill route in the back of the alcove and the last bolted route on the right side.

content.description: This starts off thin and slabby and clips 4 bolts.
content.protection: Quickdraws for 4 bolts and an anchor with Mussy hooks.
content.location:
It is the 1 bolted route left of

Scary

and the 3rd to the last bolted route on the right side.

content.description: This starts off thin and slabby. There is a loose block around the 3rd bolt in a crack - there are no issues. Move right after the 3rd bolt. The climbing eases off at the 4th bolt and below the anchors.
content.protection: Quickdraws for 4 bolts to an anchor with 2 Mussy hooks.
content.location:
It is the 1 bolted route left of

Stone

and the 2nd to the last bolted route on the right side.

content.description: This starts off thin and slabby, climbing past 4 bolts.
content.protection: Quickdraws for 4 bolts and a 2 Mussy hook anchor.
content.location: It is the 1 bolted route left of Z-Crack, the 4th to the last bolted route on the right side, and the 2nd bolted route on the west face.

content.description: The initial moves are 5.7, and the climbing past the last 3 bolts are 5 easy.
content.protection:
Quickdraws for 4 bolts and a shared anchor (with

Happy

, 5.9, to the right) with 2 Mussy hooks.
content.location:
It is 1 bolted route left of

Happy

. This is the 1st bolted route on the left side of West Face of Trail Creek. Start on a corner or arete before going around corner left to "Bulges, 5.10," or "Different Kind,5.9".

content.description:
This route is described in the Jim Shaw "

Fraser Valley Climbs

" guidebook as having an overhanging and boulder type start. The route has 4 total bolts plus 2 anchors.

Details:

This route is short and hard.

After clipping the 2nd bolts, there is a minor rest before heading into the corner.

The finish is still steep. Some crimping and stemming will get you to the anchors.
content.location:
This route is at the lowest point on the wall, directly left and around the corner from

Elliot

. Or it could also be described as the 2nd route from left to right.
